Why is dual camera not supported?

Dual camera recording requires your device to operate both front and back cameras simultaneously. This is a hardware capability that depends on your device\'s processor and camera hardware. Most flagship phones from 2020 onwards support this feature. Mid-range and older devices typically do not.\n\nThis is NOT a bug ‚Äî it\'s a hardware limitation of your device.
Devices with Qualcomm Snapdragon 855 or newer, Google Tensor, Samsung Exynos 990 or newer, and MediaTek Dimensity 1000 or newer typically support concurrent camera access.

Everything you need to know about the built-in editor

Pick any video from your device or your FadCam recordings. Trim it frame-by-frame using the timeline, then export. All processing happens locally on your device ‚Äî nothing is uploaded.\n\nYour editing progress is auto-saved every few seconds and whenever you leave the editor, so no work is lost if the app closes unexpectedly.

FadCam records in a crash-safe format called fragmented MP4 (fMP4). Unlike a standard MP4 which has one finalized container, fMP4 writes video in small independent chunks. This means your footage stays intact even if the app crashes or recording stops suddenly.

However, external video players, gallery apps, and file managers will not be able to seek, scrub, or display the correct duration of these files. This is not a bug ‚Äî it is a deliberate design trade-off for reliability.

If you plan to store your videos outside FadCam ‚Äî on Google Drive, a computer, or any other location ‚Äî you must convert them first. Otherwise the files will be unusable for normal playback.

To convert: simply open the video here in Faditor Mini and tap Export. The converted standard MP4 will appear in your Records tab, ready to save to your gallery or share anywhere. The process is instant and lossless ‚Äî no re-encoding or quality loss.

Exported videos are saved to your active storage location (the same one configured in Settings) with the prefix \"Faditor_\" followed by a timestamp. They appear in the Records tab alongside your original recordings.
During editing, temporary cache files may be created for preview optimization. These are automatically cleaned up after export and do not consume permanent storage.

All your editing sessions are shown for quick access. Each project is stored as a small JSON file on your device containing the video URI, trim points, and timestamps ‚Äî no copies of your videos are made. Projects are auto-saved every few seconds, so your progress is never lost.\n\nYou can delete projects you no longer need using the multi-select checklist icon. Deleting a project only removes the editing session data; your original video files remain untouched.

Fragmented MP4 Format

FadCam uses a fragmented MP4 format for recordings. This means videos are saved in small segments instead of one complete file. The benefit is that if something goes wrong during recording, you only lose the last few seconds instead of the entire video.

If the last few seconds of your video appear frozen or stale, don\'t worry ‚Äî it\'s not a bug! When you stop recording, the current fragment may still complete its cycle (~3 seconds), which can leave a brief stale frame at the end.

Player Limitations

The built-in video player has some Android system limitations. You may notice the progress bar or waveform appearing slightly snappy ‚Äî this is normal behavior and not a bug.

For the smoothest playback experience, you can use an external player like VLC. That said, the integrated player works well for everyday use!
